title: At what grade should you start preparing for the SAT exam? - Quora

response.answer_text: As someone who has worked in the test-prep industry for 23 years I can give you some really good insight into this. I would say the EARLIEST that you should start preparing is the Summer between freshman and sophomore year. In that case you would be preparing him to take the PSAT-10 (which is very similar to the SAT). However, I even feel that is too early. Summer between sophomore and year is the optimal time to prepare. That way he can spend some of the “off” time preparing, get ready for the PSAT, and then get ready for the SAT some time after that (November or December). That will give him enough time to see his scores, evaluate them, and then perhaps take the test again in the spring (March, May, or June). This plan usually works out well because it will give him enough time to take additional tests (if needed) such as the ACT and/or SAT Subject tests. You’ll want to have him focus on his school work and keep those grades up. His GPA will be the most important factor in college admissions. Also, extremely important that he takes time to do things he enjoys and not spend all his time worrying about testing and school. Hope that helps.

Since birth. Joking. A2A. Contrary to popular thought, standardized exams such as the SAT or the ACT is best done when prepared rigorously for a short period of time (3–4 months). A lot of students prepare for 1+ years, and this actually ends up having a negative effect because you will eventually exhaust your energy in what is, after all, very tedious work. As a veteran instructor, I will tell you that none of my students have ever worked with me for more than 5 months maximum, most only having actually worked for about 2–3 months. Personally, I prepared for the SAT & ACT for 2 months back when I was in high school, and was able to bring my score up from 1450 to 2330 on the SAT and 28 to 35 on the ACT.

As others have said, you should prepare your child for the PSAT since your child is likely to take the PSAT before the SAT. The PSAT is used in a student’s junior year to determine their eligibility for the National Merit Scholarship. The results of the PSAT will also give you an indication of where your child should focus his or her SAT test prep. Having said this, my son is enrolled in a SAT prep program at our local community college. He is a sophomore. But he is the sort of student who needs structure and can’t be relied upon to self-direct his test prep.

These are some great responses, so I just wanted to mention the importance of the PSAT in October of your Junior year (11th grade in the US). Many college-bound students start taking the test in 8th grade. It will give you an idea of the Math and English skills you will need to focus upon in high school, at least if you want to do well on the SAT with very little formal test prep. Good luck to all you future test takers!

As a procedural practice, you should prepare about a year before the test. A plan with respect to reading someone’s test overview and practice of their problems will be good preparation. You need to understand that all your pre-college education is preparation for this standardized test. It includes all your experiences in life outside such education as well. This test is standardized and intended for academic application, but its principles are widespread to any long-term job. It is a test that all undergraduate institutions agree upon for standardized evaluation and admission into the next educational step.

You should apply for the SAT when you're in class 11. Give the test in October or December. This way, you'll have the option of taking the test again to improve your score and wouldn't miss any deadlines. Apart from the SAT, you need to give either TOEFL or IELTS. If you're targetting only American universities, then give TOEFL and if you wish to apply to other countries as well, then give IELTS. Hope this helps. Good luck!

Hey, for the SAT, I would say a well planned training of about 4-5 months is more than enough. So start about 4-5 months prior to when you’re planning to apply for admission. And it’s really important to enroll in a proper coaching institute for SAT, since your SAT score is one of the most important points of consideration in your college application. You can try Manya-The Princeton Review, my cousin took coaching from them last year and he was quite impressed by how much attention they pay to their students. As a student fresh out of school, you really need an experienced institute to guide you and I believe Manya can do that for you. All the best for your exam.

If you want to maximize your studying plan, do SAT prep as early as possible. I started the summer before my sophomore year and it has helped immensely. I have never been good at test taking and I really needed that extra year to go over my weaknesses (especially in Math). Better to get a headstart on the SAT than take your first SAT in senior year.

You should start preparing in class 11th or 12th as there’s no point in starting too early (Atleast that what’s I think based on my experience) but make sure that you start it atleast 2–3 months before the test (That’s what I did and I got a decent score) thats just the right period to do it, I suggest you not to do it too early. 2–3 months is a great time to prepare for your SAT and get a great score. Best of luck for your exam..! Cheers..!

If you want to receive a high score, earlier the better. I did start prepping for SAT’s when I was in 10th grade. I first took PSAT’s in 11th grade and then completed by SAT’s including the Subject Test by early Spring of my senior year. English is not my mother tongue,however, English is the first language I learned.

For Indian students, the ideal time to start the SAT preparation would be after 10th-grade board exams. Students will be a little free for at least the next three months after completing the 10th exams before they get packed with 11th and 12th-grade school tasks. Most of the topics tested in the SAT are covered in the 10th class, so it is neither too early nor too late.

Usually preparation is not needed until one's 11th grade year. You could begin your preparation the summer before 11th grade if you know your Junior year is going to be full of high level classes, extracurriculars, and lots of college admissions work.
Ninth grade. Read a LOT! Write down the definition to every word you don't know. Study math, get tutors if you need them, summer school, whatever it takes.
